texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On some occasions, MySQL replication can break down if an statement comes from the master that makes no sense to the slave. For example, if an UPDATE statement arrives from the master server, but the table referenced by the UPDATE no longer exists, then the slave will halt replication and throw an error when
texts.text: On some occasions, MySQL replication can break down if an statement comes from the master that makes no sense to the slave. For example, if an UPDATE statement arrives from the master server, but the table referenced by the UPDATE no longer exists, then the slave will halt replication and throw an error when

texts.label: code
texts.orig: SHOW SLAVE STATUS;
texts.text: SHOW SLAVE STATUS;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: is run.
texts.text: is run.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The obvious question here is: how can the master and the slave have different data after replication has started? After all, you make a dump file prior to starting replication, so both servers contain the same information. Stray updates can be thrown into the mix from application errors or plain user errors. These kinds of things happen, even though we all try to avoid it.
texts.text: The obvious question here is: how can the master and the slave have different data after replication has started? After all, you make a dump file prior to starting replication, so both servers contain the same information. Stray updates can be thrown into the mix from application errors or plain user errors. These kinds of things happen, even though we all try to avoid it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Don't worry - this is almost always an easy fix. You have two main options:
texts.text: Don't worry - this is almost always an easy fix. You have two main options:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fix the problem yourself.  If the master sent a query that the slave can't run, fix it manually. For example, if the master wants to run an INSERT on a table that doesn't exist, run a quick
texts.text: Fix the problem yourself.  If the master sent a query that the slave can't run, fix it manually. For example, if the master wants to run an INSERT on a table that doesn't exist, run a quick

texts.label: code
texts.orig: SHOW CREATE TABLE;
texts.text: SHOW CREATE TABLE;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: on the master and create the table manually on the slave. When the table is there, run a
texts.text: on the master and create the table manually on the slave. When the table is there, run a

texts.label: code
texts.orig: START SLAVE;
texts.text: START SLAVE;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: on the slave and you should be all set.
texts.text: on the slave and you should be all set.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Skip an unnecessary query.  Let's say that the master sent over a
texts.text: Skip an unnecessary query.  Let's say that the master sent over a

texts.label: code
texts.orig: DROP TABLE
texts.text: DROP TABLE

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: query but the table doesn't exist on the master. It's safe to say that the master won't be sending any write queries to that table in the future, so the query can be skipped. To skip it, run the following statement:
texts.text: query but the table doesn't exist on the master. It's safe to say that the master won't be sending any write queries to that table in the future, so the query can be skipped. To skip it, run the following statement:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
mysql> SET GLOBAL SQL_SLAVE_SKIP_COUNTER = 1;
mysql> START SLAVE;
texts.text:
mysql> SET GLOBAL SQL_SLAVE_SKIP_COUNTER = 1;
mysql> START SLAVE;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In short, you're telling MySQL to skip that unnecessary query and keep going with the ones after that. Of course, if you need to skip multiple queries, change the 1 to whatever number you need and then run
texts.text: In short, you're telling MySQL to skip that unnecessary query and keep going with the ones after that. Of course, if you need to skip multiple queries, change the 1 to whatever number you need and then run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: START SLAVE;
texts.text: START SLAVE;
